description:
Yumm! Loved the bibimbap that I got. I ordered for takeout and went for the beef, pork, and tofu in the bowl. The beef was really well marinated as well as the pork. The tofu tasted really good with the sauce that came with the bibimbap. The pickled vegetables were super tasty and a combination of sweet and savory. 

Overall a very good bowl!
author: Valeria S.

description:
Build-your-own-bowl places are my jam, and BibimBar does it Korean style. This place is tucked away in the downstairs international food court, so you won't find it unless you know what you're looking for.

Base options: brown rice, white rice, japchae, lettuce
Protein options: bulgogi beef, grilled chicken, spicy pork belly, tofu
Veggie toppings: lettuce, red cabbage, pickled radish, carrot, sauteed onions, bean sprouts
Sauce options: gochujang, super spicy,...and a few others, but why would you get anything other than the two I just listed?
You can also throw an over-medium egg or sauteed kimchi on top for extra.

Flavor is excellent, service is quick, and price is very reasonable. Only complaint is that sometimes the brown rice looks a bit like instant rice in terms of quality. BibimBar has been a lifesaver whenever I'm craving something more flavorful yet healthy for lunch. It's the closest San Francisco has to SoCal's Bibibop or Bibigo for now. Will definitely miss it when I no longer work in FiDi :'(
author: Tim X.

description: This is my go to lunch spot when I'm in this part of the city the food is great and it comes out fast, the only issue is cleanliness of the seating areas as it's in a food court basement but that's not the restaurants fault per we but it makes the dining experience more difficult for sure.
author: Christian O.

description: Great place for Korean food. The ordering system is very similar to Chipotle. I ordered the bulgogi beef with some sauces on top and was very happy with my meal. Staff was very friendly. For $10 plus tip it was fantastic. The food court has a busser and it was nice to easily leave after a meal.
author: Kristie D.

description:
TLDR - dope spot for a quick grab and go, tech bro paradise.

The international food market is one of the best spots to go for food in the area. It's a food court so it gets pretty packed during workday lunch hour

Bibimbar is nice - it allows you to choose what you want in your bowl so you can hit it with the health lettuce grind or the high key japchae grind depending on your mood for the day. It's a solid choice and it I've been back a few times.

The pork is delicious, chicken is good too although I prefer the pork. Honestly just follow the stars on the menu lol. 

Cleanliness wise, this place is great granted you're good with chopsticks. You could theoretically eat while working but this isn't as easy as dumplings to chow down on while pushing out some high priority features.

Pro tip - you can straight up buy a jar of kimchi here. I did that ish and have been using it with my dinner pretty often
author: Samraaj B.

description:
Check it

International Food Court is the diverse sound
Sneakers in dress shirts roam underground
Lunchtime junkies line up for BiBimBar 
Fermented cabbage from the Kimchi Jar
Stone bowl classic that's that dine in only
Vegan friendly testimony
Japchae noodles make your case
Or classic rice done be my base
Weekday diet need that weight relief
But finding 'golgi beef lodged between my teeth
Crave the protein biceps big
One dollar extra to dig that Egg
Do that sauce do Super Spicy
Sweating bullets that's super dicey
Budget lunch FiDi midday bunch
Under $12 love that crunch time lunch

foodkid fAATcity
author: Ringo M.

description: I got brown rice bowl, all veggies, kimchi and egg. Growing up from South Cal with lots of Korean markets and restaurants near my neighbourhood, this bibimbap is pretty disappointing honestly. Most of the veggies are not stir fried like how bimbimbap should be but just salad (lettuce, carrots and all) from the salad bag. Also when I picked up my take-away bowl, I noticed it's visibly lesser in quantity than when you eat in. I don't think the price justified what you get in the bowl.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Sadly, there are not many Korean BBQ spots around FiDi, so it's nice that BimbimBar is conveniently-located in the area. But being in the International Food Court, it's bit hard to spot. 

I ordered my food online and went to pick it up. I chose a regular bowl, which includes a base (white/brown rice, japchae, or lettuce) vegetables (lettuce, carrots, purple cabbage, onions, radish, and bean sprouts), and sauce (medium/super spicy, sesame teriyaki, seasoned soy, orange-ginger, and mayo-racha). I ordered white rice with all veggies minus the radishes, and my meat toppings as the bulgogi beef and the spicy pork belly (It was $2 extra for each meat topping).

My rice was a bit soggy and made the meal a little less enjoyable. And my bowl had the radishes even though I ordered them without, but the place was fairly busy at prime lunch time, so I can see how things were probably hectic. The meat was pretty good. Both the pork belly and the beef were tasty and very flavorful. I was expecting less meat, but there was a decent amount. Overall, it was a good meal. 

Quick, tasty, and fairly-priced = great lunch option.
author: Meghan J.

description:
Great food in the international food court. Got the japchae in the stone bowl with braised tofu and kimchi and it was delicious.

Fast casual restaurant in a basement with a lot of international food options around. Good amount of seating and nice to have options if you're with a group 

You get to choose which veggies (onion, radish, cabbage, bean sprouts, carrots, maybe another), proteins, and sauce. Each protein is an additional charge to the bowl. Racha mayo and ginger sauce were good together and didn't overwhelm any other flavors of the bowl. Hot stone bowl was for sure worth it. Pretty oily but not too the point where you feel gross. 

Overall great experience and look forward to coming back soon
author: Bito M.

description: Bibimbap in hot stone is the real deal. I normally get Japche and Brown rice half & half with medium spicy sauce.
author: Madhu J.

description:
It's like the Chipotle of Korean bibimbap. Pick your base, veggies, protein, and sauce to get your custom bowl of bibmbap. 

If you're eating it there, you have the option of having it served in a sizzling bowl which could be really comforting on a wet and cold day. I had a regular bowl delivered via UberEats so no sizzling theatrics for me. What I did get though was a well-balanced bowl of rice, veggies, pickles, kimchi, and grilled salmon as my main protein. Other protein options include chicken, bulgogi beef, and spicy pork belly or you could keep it vegetarian and add tofu. The gochujang binds all the ingredients together with a mildly spicy kick. (You can opt for the really spicy option or other sauces like teriyaki). Bowls should top out around the $10 mark except for the salmon version.   

It's Asian comfort food for lunch and BiBimBar gets it to hungry but time-strapped office workers fast and efficiently.
author: Jon L.

description:
Very solid lunch spot if you aren't looking to wait too long in line and want good food.

The line here is always the longest out of all the options here. I usually get the japchae base, all the veggies, spicy pork belly (it's not spicy), extra fried egg (+$1) and the medium spicy sauce. 

The medium spicy sauce isn't spicy, but I've witnessed my coworker crying after he ordered the extra spicy. Perhaps there is something that's just in the middle.... will need to figure that out.

Really tasty, quick, and decently priced food. Wouldn't recommend eating in the food court though bc it's not that nice.
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
I've been coming here since 2013 and I used to love this place - fast, yummy and different from other lunch spots in FiDi. However, in the recent visits, I can tell the quality of food is going down hill. Their rice - the most basic ingredient of the bowel - has been really bad compared to couple years ago. It's very dry and doesn't taste fresh (seems like the leftover from last night.) 

I hope the owner will read this and improve their quality. I've noticed that the owner hired many helpers and showed up less in the store. Hope that's not the reason why the quality is getting worse.
author: Kay H.

description:
Not bad for Korean fast food! I got the basic bowl with japchae, bulgogi, and teriyaki sauce. Loved the bulgogi! Very tasty and well cooked. I tried my boyfriend's spicy tofu too and it was yummy. 

Always happy to find good dishes in downtown San Francisco for under $10. Service was fine too.
author: Emma W.

description:
Modern-style Korean food for less than $10 in the Fidi? I'll take it!

My usual order consist of:
-JapChae noodles
-ALL the veggie! And they give you a lot!
-$1 tofu add-on
-Medium Spicy sauce

It's a very generous amount of food, and it still comes out less than $10.
I like that protein price is added on separately, so that if you're vegetarian/vegan, you can just get rice/noodles with veggies for a cheaper price.

The combination of the fresh veggies mixed with the spicy tofu is perfect. The noodles are simple, but soft and go well with everything else. They also have hot stone bowls available for dine-in only, which I've never done but would really like to try.
author: Lanie L.

description:
Yum. First time to the international food court not too long ago. And first time trying Bibimbar and I'd return. 

The stall gets busy around lunch time. We got there and was lucky and only had a couple ahead of us but by the time it was our turn, like a couple of minutes, there was a significantly longer line. 

A pretty good process, think burrito line, but for Korean! Ha so smart. You choose if you want a bowl or stone bowl. If you want a stone bowl to get the nice crispy rice at the bottom, it's $1 more, but in my opinion totally worth it for that extra flavor and texture. They put the bowl on the fire to heat it. Of course, this is also if you have enough time to eat it because it doesn't stay much hotter so, if you're rushing, then a bowl is likely best. 

Choose your bowl, base, meat/toppings, sauce. They also note vegan or gluten free options which is cool too. 

We got two orders, one order was half rice half japchae, marinated chicken, with all veggies, and medium spicy in a stone bowl. It was very satisfying and yummy especially on colder day. 

The other was the spicy pork that was in a bowl. It was tasty too. 

Overall, I'd be back, it's good :)

Tip: try to go slightly before the lunch rush just to get in line sooner 
Tip2: as I said above, stone bowl if you have time and want crispy rice. If you're rushing, then probably a bowl is better.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This place is a great find in this unassuming underground international food court. You'll quickly notice this is one of the places with the longest lines out of the vendors in there. 

They offer stone bowls and regular bowls. Regular bowls (and to-go orders) will get you through the line and out the door quickly. Stone bowls are another story. On multiple occasions I've seen people waiting around for the tone bowls to free up (they have to go pick them up from around the court, clean them, and hear them up). Needless to say stone bowls are not the way to go if you are in a hurry. But enough about that. Onto the food. 

Every time I've come here I have gotten the exact same thing. The bulgogi with the japchae. It's awesome, filling, and reasonably priced. However, beware with the super spicy sauce. I would assume the overwhelming majority of the lunch patrons are on their lunch break, and assuming you don't wanna come back to your office dripping in sweat - I would stay away from the super spicy sauce. I should probably mention that I love spicy food and it wasn't necessarily the spice that was unbearable, but, but I just started to sweat profusely. The medium spicy sauce will do just fine and you won't go back to work looking like you just showered. 

The stone bowls are heated and they are very cool but don't really add/take away any flavor (although they do make for some pretty cool snapchats/ IG pictures). Get it once and then get regular bowls and you'll find yourself sliding right though the line. 

Bulgogi is really well seasoned, and it comes with a sizable amount of vegetables as well so you can convince yourself you're being "healthy". Pro tip: add an egg on there. Your welcome. 

They have a variety of other offerings, but I honestly can't even see myself getting anything other then the bulgogi with japchae (with medium spicy sauce) because I got so hooked! I'm definitely a fan.
author: Thielson D.

description:
Walk down the small staircase located off the corner of Bush and Kearny and you'll find this underground food court of Asian fusion, burgers and fries and the delicious BibimBar. I came here for the first time last week during lunch hour and almost immediately walked out when I saw the super unclean conditions of the food court area. But, with a decent line of hungry FiDi workers I figured it can't be too bad, and I was also starving so decided to give it a try. 

BibimBar offers a simple menu with choose your base, protein, mixed in veggies and sauce.  I went for the Soba Noodle bowl, all the veggies (lettuce, cabbage, carrot, arugula, onion, radish, and bean sprouts) topped with the Tofu and orange ginger sauce. The workers assured me everything was vegan (yay) and the service was quick. The MASSIVE bowl came out to be around $10 so for lunch in the FiDi I say that's a pretty good deal. 

Overall, the bowl was decent, nothing over the top amazing but it was filling.  The veggies and noodles were delicious and the orange ginger sauce gave it a nice zing. I was a bit disappointed in the tofu, it was kinda mushy and lacking a bit of flavor so I did add some extra hot sauce (which was damn hot even though I got the 'mild') that flavored it up a bit. I don't work around here, but If i worked in the area I would probably come back here more often for a quick and filling lunch.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
There are not many times where a food stand in a underground food court is this good. The restaurant is in the International Food Court off Kearny Street. You'll have to watch out for a Bibimbar sign outside and a little storefront that says International Food Court and walk down stairs. The food court gets super packed at lunch time and I've always seen a line at Bibimbar. 

This is just a solid lunch option. For around $10, you get fresh ingredients and a turn from the usual salad and sandwich. It's good Korean food in a friendly form. Make your own rice bowl and have to go or in a sizzling stone spot. Either way, it's delicious and good for you!
author: Kelly N.

description: The customization part of this little place is definitely a plus because you get to choose it to your liking. The food is really flavorful and resembles really close to a traditional bimbimbap. The service is really quick, but the staff can be a bit attitudy.
author: Alina Y.

description:
Fun little hole in the wall restaurant in the International cafeteria style. You go down some sketchy steps into this place that has 7 or 8 different restaurants there: Mexican, Indian, Korean, Japanese, Russian. All sorts of fun!

Good food and good prices, and great service.
author: Peter S.

description: Delicious pork belly and vegetable combo.  Great service too.
author: Jerry G.

description: Enjoyed the spicy pork bowl to go that was part of a Mealpal.  Was nice to skip the line.  Enjoyed all the veggies and it's simple, but does the job and I'd return to try another meat again.  Never like eating in this underground place, so recommend to go, though then you don't get the stone bowl.
author: Marc S.

description:
Hidden inside the International Food Court. It's by far the busiest one inside the food court and for good reason! 

Really good and fast- it's chipotle style ordering! I always get half japchae and half brown rice with all the veggies. I really appreciate that the label what is vegan and gluten-free. Everything is really fresh. 

All the add-ons can really add up. I enjoy the kimchi and tofu - both vegan. 

The only con about this place is the price. You can easily spend $10+ for not a lot of food. It's good but I still get hungry after finishing a bowl.
author: Jessica K.

description:
This is the only restaurant I've gotten food from within this small and hidden food court tucked away at the corner of Bush and Kearny.

I've been here 3 times so far and I've always had a similar experience. You pick a base (white rice, brown rice, japchea, soba noodles, or lettuce) and then have various proteins and veggies added on with a sauce of your choice to mix it all up. The veggies are all included, but you have to pay extra for each meat and also if you want an egg.

I enjoy all the veggies and meat they add to the bowl but always end up with too much sauce to the point where the rice at the very bottom is overly salty and soggy. I'm not sure if it's because I always get the same sauce (seasoned soy sauce) but inevitably I end up with this sad bowl of soggy rice at the end.

Bowls usually run around $11-12 for me, though of course this all depends on what proteins you decide to add.
author: Dianna H.

description: I go there almost every weekday and their bibimbap is incredible, generous, tasty and pretty cheap!
author: Leo A.

description:
First time at BipimBar. Stopped by for a quick lunch while waiting for my wife's business meeting to end. It was a bit hard to find, being underground but I'm so glad I persisted. 

There was an excellent value here because for about $11 I got a filling, savory, multi-texture meal. Here's what you do:
Select small or large (stone) bowl (I got the large one). 
Pick a base - white rice, brown rice or japchae (noodles), I got brown rice. 
Toppings area choice of tofu, kimchi, fried egg, marinated chicken, spicy pork belly, Bulgolgi, salmon. I chose Bulgolgi and kimchi (extra charge for 2). 
Sauces are medium, super hot, sesame teriyaki, seasoned soy, orange ginger. I added medium. 
Comes with kimchi tofu soup, which was unnecessary in my opinion. 

The place was packed for lunch 11:50 AM but it was a food court which offered six restaurants: Japan, Mexico, French Vietnamese, Thai, Korean and American. 

I recommend BipimBar for a quick, multi-option lunch.
author: Jeff B.

description:
I LOVE! I love bibimbap style bowls & this place allows for customization of your own bowls. First, you choose a warm or cold base. Cold bases is salad or soba noodles, you can't do half and half for this. Warm bases are white rice, brown rice or japchae (silver noodle), you CAN do half and half for this. Then you choose your veggies and your sauce. If you add meat, it'll be an additional charge but of course you should add your meat! :) 

I got the soba noodles w/ all the veggies & chicken w/ orange ginger sauce. It was super delicious & the perfect light and hearty meal with lots of veggies! 

This place closes at 2-230 PM depending on what day it is. It's in a food court underground across from Starbucks. 

I want this again!!
author: Winnie L.

description: Good food but the portions are too small to justify the $11+ price! Had the bowl with japjae and bulgogi. Good selection of veggies and hot sauce is delicious. But, I was barely full after my lunch... there are better options nearby: Henry's Cafe & Deli (https://www.yelp.com/biz/henrys-cafe-and-deli-san-francisco-2)
author: Raj S.

description:
$10.88 for a warm meal of brown rice, grilled chicken and vegetables. Would recommend the medium spicy sauce.

Sure, it's kind of ghetto and the food is not the highest quality (questionable looking beef/pork/fried egg sitting there) but bang for buck here is pretty amazing for SF standards. 

Great for lunch if you're craving some cheap Korean.
author: Kristie C.

description:
I was really excited to try this place because I used to walk past their sign announcing their stone bowl bibimbap. When I finally waited in line to try the place, I realized you can only get a stone pot if you're eating in, and I was sadly going to take it to-go. There was a line but when the person got to the front, they were served their food quickly.

For your base, you get a choice of white rice, brown rice, japchae (glass noodles), or lettuce as your base. Not sure if you can do half and half (seems like they'd allow it). I ordered japchae with spicy pork (+$2), all the veggies, fried egg (+$1), and medium spicy sauce (gochujang). Total came out to be $11.88.

The japchae tasted good and had the bouncy chewiness I was craving. The sauce mixed with the veggies and japchae was a nice addition. I wasn't a fan of the pork belly; it wasn't as tender as I expected, so to me, it didn't provide a great flavor. Next time I'll try the bulgolgi and kimchi.

Overall, a great place for your Korean food fix in a short amount of time. Would come again!
author: Serena W.

description: There aren't many places in downtown to go to when you are craving Korean food. Luckily, Bibimbar is a fast and efficient way to get your cravings satisfied. Service was really friendly and efficient. You move down the line and tell them what you want- Chipotle style. I ordered the beef bulgogi w/ half noodles and half brown rice (w/ all veggies) in a stone bowl. If you are in a hurry, I recommend just getting a regular bowl because my rice didn't really become crispy on the bottom ( I think I ate too fast and didn't let the rice crisp up tho). For around $10, Bibimbar is a yummy option compared to all the other lunch options in downtown. I recommend trying it at least once.
author: Eva L.

description:
Pretty good when it comes to price, location, and food for lunch. 

The food court this place is located in is kiiiinda sketch on sanitation, and pretty crowded but the line is always longest for Bibimbar (probably cause its the best lunch spot in the court). Its kind of a chipotle for Korean lunch bowls. You can choose from a sizzling stone bowl (+$1 extra) or regular bowl and from there you can choose the starch, veggies, and protein (another +$1 for a sunnyside up egg) added to it. 


Over all great portions, a bit oily, but pretty filling. 

Some protips: 
- eat there, they give you more food and you get free kimchi soup
- you can mix glass noodles AND rice if you cant decide,  I usually get a little brown rice on the bottom of my sizzle stone bowl so it gets nice and crispy and add noodles. 
- ask for more veggies if you want- they're usually pretty nice about giving you a bit more. (;
author: Maggie Y.

description: i wish i could give this place a higher rating.  i went and got a pre-packaged lunch.  tofu and bulgolgi rice bowl.  a sauce cup was included.  the sauce with the meat was very good together.  the reason for the rating is the quantity of beef was not enough. probably like 10% of the meal.  there was also white rice, carrot, pickled vegetable and red cabbage also.  the tofu was a little bland.  i would go back, but its just an okay this time.
author: Richard M.

description:
Solid  lunch spot. Food is very tasty but greasy. Overall there are a lot of good lunch options in the immediate area and I would probably only come if I were craving bibimbap

Price is on par with other SF lunch. I paid $10.80 for a regular bowl w/ japchae, veggies, bulgogi and sauce.

The setup is like chipotle- build your bowl and move down the line so you can get your food very fast depending on the line.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Chipotle-esque build your own bibimbap (Korean rice bowl) station tucked inside the International Food Cout. Great place to grab a tasty and affordable lunch in FiDi. Don't let the line scare you- they are fast! 

+$7.50 for standard carb and veggies
+$1 for stone pot
+$2 for bulgogi
+$1 for sunny side up egg
=100% delicious

I recommend getting the orange ginger sauce. Mmm
author: Lucy N.

description:
This is a go-to spot of mine. Very good food and the best in the international food court. To the point where I think they get 10x the traffic compared to the other restaurants here...combined. Kinda sad really for the other spots here.

My favorite item here and the one I would recommend is the stone rice bowl with pork. Yummmeee!
author: Sunil R.

description:
Korean food = good. Fast food Korean food = not as good.

This spot is located inside an Asian Food Court with a decent amount of seats, but not enough for the lunch crowd during a weekday lunch. After much debate about which Asian cuisine I felt like eating for that meal, I decided to get something from BibimBar (clever name BTW). I got the japchae (glass noodles) with a few sauces and chicken. Usually I'm a huge fan of japchae, but it was just okay here. The sauces were okay and the veggies they put on top were okay. There was nothing super impressive about this place, but it does get you a quick customized meal for a decent price (for SF anyways).

Overall, it was okay.
author: Sophia Y.

description: As far as I'm concerned, BibimBar has delicious bibimbap that is very easy to customize and comes at a reasonable price. I came on a rainy day and the hot bowl was perfect for lifting my mood. I also like the availability of brown rice and noodles. I didn't see a lot of bibimbap available around the Financial District, so BibimBar was a great option, even if the atmosphere for the seating of the food court is a little lacking.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Nestled within an Asian food court that looked like it could be violating fire code, Bibimbar serves Korean food with a Chipotle-style ordering line. It focuses on one of my favourite dishes - bibimbap, which is usually many different mixed or stir-fried dishes on top of rice. Here, you can pick a japchae base or a rice base, veggies, a protein, and a sauce. You can also get it in a stone pot, which is extra nice for the sizzling rice effect. 

The food was decent for food court food. The flavours were good, just a little on the small side comparing to normal bibimbaps, and nowhere near as spicy even if you get the spicy sauce. It is a great alternative to sandwiches or burritos though, especially if you like to pick out every single part of your meal.
author: Alice C.

description:
Had a bibimbap here for lunch! Very quick/no line even though the food court is usually pretty busy which is nice.

For the bowl, you can have a regular plastic bowl or the stone bowl (which costs $1 extra but comes with hot rice). You have a choice of brown rice, white rice or japchae for your base and then they usually give you the assortment of the basics. If you want meat, it's either $1.50 for the chicken or $2 for bulgogi. The fried egg is $1 so your meal ends up around $10 if you get everything in it. The portion sizes are fairly reasonable for lunch. You won't be hungry after you eat here but you also won't be very full if you come here while famished. A small bowl of kimchi soup comes with each order. Surprisingly, the kimchi soup may have been the best part of my meal. It was very tasty!

Definitely one of the better options at the International Food Court!
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Food court cuisine at its finest!  A little Chipotle-esqe with all the starch, veggie, meat and sauce choices served in a fast casual manner.  But if you eat it in the food dungeon, you can upgrade to a hot stone bowl that will crisp your rice and keep your food warm.  Ends up being a bit cheaper than ordering dolsot bibimbap in a waiter service restaurant.

Kimchi Tofu Soup: More exciting than the free miso soup that Japanese places often give you.  Reminded me a bit of cabbage borscht since the cabbage flavor dominated the soup more than the pickled or spicy flavors of the kimchi.  Just enough tofu to give some morsels of texture, but nothing like a soondubu.

Spicy Pork Belly in Stone Bowl: I've tried the various meats and the spicy pork belly is definitely my favorite.  It's like triple thick bacon that is mostly firm on the outside with some tender section in the center.  The spicy sauce adds a nice accompaniment and, since it's already giving you a kick, you can feel free to order a not-so-spicy sauce at the end like orange ginger.  The raw veggies (carrots, red cabbage) were crisp and fresh while the pickled and cooked veggies each had their own nice flavor and texture profile.  I was partially tempted to eat each one separately, but then that notion passed and I mixed it all together per usual.  With the stone bowl I like to have a thin layer of white rice on the bottom, so it gets nice and crispy, and then some slimy (in a good way) sweet potato noodles on top.  The staff seems happy to oblige my quirky starch order.
author: Adam B.

description:
3.5 stars.

Located inside the International Food Court (look for the awning when you're on the street and then go downstairs). The weekday lunch line is always long, and since it's a busy food court, there's not a ton of seating for groups.

Build your own bibimbap bowl
- Base in regular bowl is something like $7.50 and comes with:
Choice of starch- sweet potato noodles/japchae, brown rice, white rice
Veggies- bean sprouts, cabbage, greens, carrots, etc
Choice of sauce- spicy, super spicy, orange ginger, teriyaki, etc
- Extras:
Stone bowl ($1)
Meat- chicken ($1.50), bulgogi ($2), pork belly ($2)
Sunny side up egg ($1)

Food is tasty and well-portioned. It's also nice to customize, but it can add up pretty quickly when you get the base + stone bowl + bulgogi + egg. Also, last time, my friend's stone bowl just wasn't hot enough, so it was kind of a waste.

If you get the japchae though, I'd skip the stone bowl. The stone bowl is great for creating a crispy bottom to the starch, and crispy noodles just isn't the same as crispy rice. Save the $1 and get the egg instead.

Takes credit card. Meal comes with a kimchi soup.
author: Alice T.

description:
If you are in the area and craving a light, healthy lunch that will get you going for hours,
this is the spot to get it. Rice mixed with tons of herbs and sides. My favorite
is in hot stone topped with an egg.
author: Yiannis V.

description: So this review is for a while back when I came to visit. The food took a while cuz the tofu wasn't ready and the worker couldn't tell me how long it would take to get it ready. Also she didn't listen carefully about me having spicy pork, kimchi, and tofu. When I heard that the tofu wasn't ready, I told her to omit it out but it seemed like she didn't hear me or just ignored me. When I got the food, I noticed the meat was beef and told the cashier that the wrong meat was put in. So the cashier said she would remake it for me and was kind about it. However the other lady seemed a bit peeved that she had to remake something that she had originally put in wrong in my bowl. I may come back but I'm not sure and I'm not in the city too often. And now I heard the cashier isn't working there anymore, which is too bad cuz I heard she was the Korean face of the restaurant and was really friendly.
author: Sophie S.

description:
My go-to lunch spot for Korean food in downtown! I love the personalization to choose the base, veggies, toppings, and sauces. My typical bowl is half brown rice half japchae, all veggies, spicy pork belly, fried egg, and the teriyaki sauce, along with a side kimchi.

The line during lunch hour looks long but it actually goes pretty fast. The operation is similar to Chipotle or Subway so it's very efficient. If you know what you want already, they can build your bowl in less than a minute - that's time saved from our already short lunch break.
author: Kathleen K.

description: Food is average / subpar fast korean food but I got so much attitude by the girl who was serving me for no reason and got so little of the stuff they put in, that my bowl was basically a third full. Sorabol (closeby) is a lot better in terms of quality, quantity and especially service.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Decided to finally try this place. Place looked a little dirty and like the food has been sitting. Got there at around 1:30pm to avoid the lunch time rush.

Ordered my bowl with white rice, spicy pork, and added an egg. I forgot to add kimchi but now that I think of it, I didn't see any. Paid around $11 bucks and they build it right in front of you. Took it to go and ate it at work. 

Overall it was ok, good flavor when all mixed together with medium spicy sauce. Very skimp on the meat. Might try it again before lunch time and try and get a more fresh bowl but I'm going to give Henry's deli bibimbap a try first as I wasn't impressed coming from a place that specializes in just bibimbap..
author: Rob C.

description: I work a few blocks away from the international food court and I come here a lot for lunch. I like how they have a different variety of meats, veggies and sauces to go with my rice and noodles. I especially like the workers there, they're real cool and helpful!
author: Chris P.

description: stone bowl bibimbap is my favorite from this place when i crazy korean food at work. i get half brown rice, half japchae (clear noodle), with bulgogi, egg, kimchi as option. a perfect combo!
author: Brandon H.

description: I've always loved Korean food and this is one of the best. I like the process of ordering as you are given choices and choose what you want on the stone pot. It was really filling and a great bang for your bucks.
author: Rickie H.

description: Taste is alright but it's a pretty good work lunch option if you work at Union square & financial district. Quick, simple and light.
author: Xu C.

description: Solid Korean place in the international food court. It's a Chipotle style ordering Korean bibimbap place, where you pick between white/brown rice or rice noodles, your choice of meat, choice of veggies, and sauces. The spicy pork is pretty good - I like to get that with a mix of white rice and noodles, all the veggies, and a fried egg. It's not too expensive for lunch in the city, and it definitely hits the spot and keeps you filled through the afternoon.
author: Wayne H.

description:
3.5 

I got the noodles with bulgogi. The sauce was not spicy. It was more sweet than anything. The food made me quite gaseous. Not cool. ): 

Probably wouldn't come back even if I was in the area.
author: Dianna C.

description:
BibimBar is kinda like the Korean version of Chipotle.  I've always been curious about the International Food Court even though it's a little trek from my office.  My friend and I met up for lunch after 11:30 here.  I had to choose between the Filipino place and BibimBar but obviously went here and didn't regret it at all.  I got the dolsot bibimbap with pork belly.  They mixed for me some of the teriyaki and hot sauce to top it with.  I waited for a few minutes for it to be all assembled then walked the tray over with the heavy stone pot, bowl of comp tofu soup and my drink to one of the seats in the sitting area.  

They do sure give big portions.  For about $10 I got lots of seasoned pork belly (and it's not too much fat), fresh veggies, sliced egg and rice.  Not much of my rice got crispy though unfortunately.  Despite me getting the pork belly, I feel like it was a pretty healthy lunch, and you can even opt for brown rice and no extra charge.  But everything had lots of flavor from a "food court restaurant" and is one of the better dining options in the area.  My friend always goes with the hot stone beef.  The tofu soup was okay, but tasted a little sour (reminded me of Filipino sinigang).  I can't wait to come back to try out another combination for lunch!
author: Cat C.

description: BibimBar is a quick bibimbap shop at the International Food Court. It's custom made and they have a good tofu option for vegetarian and vegans.
author: Ed M.

description: Came here for a quick lunch and really liked the idea that I can mix and match what I want in my stone bowl bibimbap. I was also happy that they labeled which ingredient was gluten free :)
author: Michelle C.

description:
not the best location but their food is good enough for me. I like that they aren't cash only like some of the other restaurants inside the food court. 

I always order their half brown rice half noodles combo, chicken and kimchee, with the spicy sauce. I have to tell them to go light on the sauce because it does get salty after awhile. yum!
author: Ava F.

description:
A little difficult to find as this place is in the small international food court down a sketchy looking staircase in the side of the building.

However, I remember liking the meal and wanting to come back some day.
author: Wolfe S.

description:
I would've never found this place if it weren't for Yelp. It's located in an underground food court with a variety of other Asian options (Chinese, Japanese, Filipino, Vietnamese, etc) so it doesn't stand out that much from the street.

This place is essentially a Chipotle for bibimbap. You can order a bowl, hot stone bowl, wrap or guksu (cold soba noodles), and then pick a base or two (white rice, brown rice or japchae), a meat (or vegetarian), veggies and sauce.

I ordered a bowl with brown rice, chicken, all the veggie toppings and bibimbar spicy sauce on the side. The food is decent, not bad for a food court and a quick lunch to go, but the portion size is pretty small for $8.65. The chicken is pretty well cooked and flavored and I liked the pickled veggies, but the other veggies were just raw veggies like a salad.

Good for an easy lunch and it's a healthy portion size despite the price. I'd probably come back if I were craving quick Korean food, but not particularly impressed.
author: Jessie L.

description:
This is the best place in the underground food court.  For $10 you can get a very healthy Korean "salad" lunch.  It's one of the best around, go for the pork belly, that's the best.  You can also get your bibimbap with rice noodles, rice or go pure vege, if you are worried about carbs.  You choose your sauce, the ginger is pretty good, but be sure to put some spice on it, it's Korean after all.  

Sometimes they will throw in the crab soup on the side for free.
author: Chris K.

description: Some of my favorite bimimbap in the city - but to be fair haven't had it from many places. But always a treat to hit this spot for lunch. Get a hot bowl if you can stick around !
author: Rohan S.

description:
First pick your container, then your base (rice or jap chae), your meat, add some veges, sauce, and most importantly PAY.

I got the regular bowl with jap chae, bulgogi, and sesame teriyaki. When I saw the jap chae, I literally thought, what is this?! because all it was was clear noodles. No veggies, nothing. I was already disappointed. After I sat down, took a bite, mmm there's the jap chae flavor I know and love. All the disappointment disappeared. The meat was flavorful and the noodles were perfect. The only thing I disliked was the small bowl size and my food was just warm. Too used to the big bowls I get from Sorabol. Will definitely come back for lunch!
author: Benita M.

description:
My coworkers and I typically order from this place when we have in-house seminars.  The food is okay - pretty good for the price but nothing special.  

Pros - 
1.  You can customize your own bowl.  I do like that you can use japchae as your base (instead of a bowl of rice).  
2.  They give you lots of vegetables.
3.  Portions are decently size (at least to me) and it's one of the cheaper lunch options around.

Cons -
1.  The meat is fairly mediocre.
author: Carrie L.

description:
NOT A FAN OF PULLED "MEAT"

Last Wednesday my coworker bought me lunch. It was a nice gesture from her as I never asked or expected it. We were going to "The Dungeon", a downstairs food court at corner of Bush Street and Kearny Street. When I go to "The Dungeon" I go to Foogle to buy lunch. This was my first time I went to BimbimBar. The concept for your lunch bowl is you order either rice or noodles, choose of meat, and select a sauce. I wasn't sure what to order since this was my first time. On the counter there was a sign of a new item - J Bap, which is sunny side egg, rice, pulled beef, and American Cheese. I ordered this dish because like Anthony Bourdain I'm an egg slut. I liked almost everything of the dish. The mixture of rice and American cheese had a texture of macaroni and cheese.  I love that the egg was sunny side up instead of over easy as yolk tends to be creamier. When you break the egg yolk and eat it with rice and cheese the texture is similar to a risotto. I liked everything except the pulled beef. In general I don't like pulled or shredded meat because the quality it possess. I think pulled pork is overrated because it tends to be flavorless or dry. When it comes to nachos I never order shredded chicken because it makes the dish watery. There's a difference between when the meat is moist or eatery. Moist meat brings out the flavor of the meat while watery meat makes the meat flavorless. For the dish I ordered the pulled beef not only was flavorless but watered-down the dish. It turned the creamy egg yolk into a soup. If I do come here to eat again I'll make sure I'll order a meat that isn't pulled or shredded.
author: Gerald R.

description: Decent stone bowl, with plenty of options for toppings. It may be a bit tricky to find as it's located in a food court at the basement level; an outside awning says "international food court".  I got brown rice, all the vegetables, the beef bulgogi and the sunny side up egg.  Wouldn't get the egg again necessarily, and the rice at the bottom of the pot ended up being quite scorched, but it was a very satisfying meal nevertheless!
author: Emily Y.

description: Not usually a fan of bibimbap, but it's pretty tasty here! Can't go wrong with jap chae or rice!
author: Cassandra T.

description:
After naively attempting Pho Express last September, I didn't think I would be back to the dungeon this soon. I have to admit when I was a young FiDi pup back in 19-none-of-your-business, I used to come down here all the time, health code violations be damned. It was cheap eats for someone who was barely scraping by as an assistant media planner. Now all these years later, the place pretty much looks the same except BibimBar looks much fresher than the other kiosks. The concept is pretty simple - it's Chipotle meets bibimbop.

It's like the Chris Brown and Rihanna of the International Food Court without the black eye. Actually they call it "The Fresh Korean Salad Bar" which is apt since most of the ingredients in my dish were cold. In true Chipotle fashion, you first order your "style" (Bibimbop for me, of course), then your base (Brown Rice 'cause I'm watching my girlish figure), your topping (no question in my mind...Spicy Pork Belly along with a bevy of shredded veggies) and finally your sauce (upon the recommendation of the server, the Bibim Spicy...whatever that is). The $8.95 result was quite a large bowl of good-looking ingredients (see photo).

However, I have to admit I was disappointed that the only ingredient that approached lukewarm was the pork belly, which was on the slightly burnt side since I arrived after the lunch rush. In hindsight, I think my lesson learned here was that I should have gone for the Bibim Hot Stone for the extra dollar in order to get a fighting chance at a hot bowl. Otherwise it was much more like a big salad as billed. I also received a complimentary bowl of the Spicy Shrimp Soup which was a nice warm treat to offset the bowl. I would definitely give it another try with the hot stone even if it does mean another adventurous journey into the dungeon.

FOOD - 3 stars...certainly big enough but was hoping for something warmer and a bit spicier for lunch
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...it's like that scene in "The Dark Knight Rises" when Christian Bale is trying to get out of that prison pit
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...friendly enough
TOTAL - 3 stars...bibimbop go boom just a little
author: Ed U.

description: Idk if this was a one off, but my lunch here was so bland. I ordered a tofu bowl over chapchae with a fried egg. It was completely flavorless despite trying to salvage my bowl by dousing everything in gochujang. Sounds like the meat options are much better, but this is not a good option for veggie lovers.
author: Katherine Y.

description:
Honestly, this place was the best selection out of all the eateries in that underground space in my eyes. And 3 stars is a fair rating that is representative of how the food was: serviceable. 

I ordered a hot stone bowl with brown rice, all the veggies available, pulled beef, and had it topped with spicy sauce ($11). The portions themselves were generous and the beef tasted a little stringy but cooked decently enough. However, the sauce definitely tasted more sweet than spicy. Well, it's not like it's an authentic Korean stone bowl restaurant, so I was okay with it. 

It's a decent option to grab a quick lunch if you're tired of sandwiches or boxed salads (which are EVERYWHERE), but I probably wouldn't come back repeatedly for this.
author: Viet N.

description: It was my first time at the International Food Court and I was intrigued by building my own bimbimbap. The line gets super long during lunch hours but it's worth waiting for! Since I had to make a togo order, I ordered the cold bowl. I chose noodles, all veggies, spicy pork belly, and super spicy sauce. The portions were generous and my bowl was flavorful!
author: Sully B.

description:
Great option for a healthy lunch on a workday in FiDi. It's located within the International Food Court (down some stairs), and it usually has the longest line out of all the stalls there. 

You can get a rice bowl or a wrap, which is pretty neat. Each order also comes with a complementary bowl of tofu and shrimp soup if you eat it in the food court. There's usually so much food that I get a bit to go for the next meal. They also have a wide variety of sauces that you can put in your bowl, though I usually go for the traditional spicy sauce. You also have the option of brown rice or japchae (or mix). For $10.80, you can get a beef bibimbap in a hot stone pot, and the food is prepared on the spot, so you can order, eat, and go.
author: Audrey L.

description:
How many times have you descended a sketchy looking flight of stairs to find a crowd of businesspeople clamoring over Azn food?! If the answer is none, come check out IFC and make a beeline for BibimBar, a gold star among the plethora of eateries down here. 

You get to pick your style, base, toppings, & sauce. I'll parrot everyone else and say that it's Chipotle-style even though I've never stepped foot in a Chipotle. Figure out what you want before you get up there and be vocal about it otherwise you will get eyes rolled at you! D:

My favorite? Bulgogi BiBim Hot Stone with 1/2 brown rice, 1/2 japchae and whatever sauce the lady decides to throw on it. She said it was "special mix" for me the first time and special it was! Putting your faith in strangers usually works :]

I've burned both my hands + mouth eating my lunch because I'm both overeager and clumsy when I'm hungry, but totally worth it for the nurungji (scorched rice) and crispy japchae. That mixed with the tasty bulgogi and vegetables helps me reach a rare state of lunchtime zen. 
The portion you get has been enough for lunch + dinner for me multiple times. You also get a free kimchi tofu soup with a meal here. It's soothing and yummy. And did I say free? :D

BibimBar is a quick, healthy lunch that's cost-effective even by non-FiDi standards. I find it funny and sad how the line after 12 will block the whole storefront of The House of Lumpia. It's a dog eat dog world!
author: Jenny Q.

description: Went here for lunch. Quick lines, there's places to sit and eat there. The stone bowl with jaepchae, all veggies, and bulgogi was delicious. Their spicy sauce is actually spicy. Yum
author: Laura D.

description:
I liked Bibimbar more than I thought I would.  I ended up having a horrible stomach ache the next morning after eating my japchai bulgogi medium spicy bowl for lunch and then the leftovers for dinner, but I'm not sure if it was that or something else, or not food related.  I think I will go back, but probably not for a while.  I would definitely recommend ordering the medium spicy or the spicy sauce because the rest of them sounded way too sweet and keep in mind that the noodles and the meats and some of the veggies have sweetness too.  The only other time I tried Korean food, I found everything to be cloyingly sweet, so this was quite a bit better.  The basic bowl is $7.50, meat is $2.00 extra and an egg is $1.00 extra.  I didn't order the egg though, because they were pre-fried and sitting in a warming tray, so it didn't appeal to me.  But get this - if you want your food hot instead of tepid, you have to pay for a heated stone bowl.  Seems extremely silly to me.  

I can kind of see why Bibim is so popular because the food isn't bad and the price isn't bad for the fact that you can make two meals out of it, but it's not a place I would go to on a regular basis.
author: Emma H.

description:
Love this place! This is always the first suggestion I make to my coworkers when we decide to eat out for lunch. It's quick, yummy, and filling--I always end up eating only about half of my bowl and taking the leftovers home, so it's basically two meals for me! Also, I lowkey like to go here when I know I need to eat some vegetables (gotta get that fiber tho) but don't want to commit to a salad for lunch....

I usually get the hot stone bowl (the extra $1 is definitely worth it in my opinion) with spicy pork, half rice, and half noodles!
author: Gabi D.

description:
Interesting. Delicious. Clean. Plentiful.

Food = good. Easy menu. Follow the instructions, order, pay and enjoy. 

Service= efficient.  

Prices= moderate.  FiDi pricing, even for this quick spot.
author: Fannie S.

description: Mediocre food, rude staff. I think they intercepted a chicken shipment bound for a penitentiary. There are a ton of other places to choose from in the immediate area, this place is not worth it
author: George P.

description:
Yum.. Affordable lunch, huge portions, semi-healthy choice!

I come here once in a while for lunch. The lines are usually not too bad, depending when you come. The service is always quick and usually friendly.\

My Bibimbowl:
Half Japchae and half brown rice
All veggies! (I don't think they offer eggs anymore... =[)
Pork belly with kim chee... because why not!?
Hot sauce on the side!

For about 10 bucks! Noms! The portions are usually huge (depending on who makes it), but it is enough for about 1 1/2 meal for me =]

The food is fresh, though not as authentic as korean restaurants, but close enough. I just wish they didn't burn the pork belly so much! grrrr!! 

A lot of people get it with the stone pot ($1 more), but i eat slow already, so having to eat something that isn't cooling down any time soon, doesn't seem like a smart idea for me.

Overall, a good place to eat lunch, even if you grab to go. Plenty of seating. Quick Service. Fair Prices. =]

I will be back!!!
author: Judy W.

description: In SF for work from San Jose.  Looked on yelp and this place had good reviews and decided since it's in an international food court i could try another place if it didn't look good.  Waited in line for 51 seconds (yes i counted) and ordered the bowl with white rice, bulgogi, and spicy pork belly.  Lady asked me "with everything?" I said "have you seen this body?  Of course i want everything!"  I didn't expect much since it's fast food but this place is truly amazing.  Great flavor.  Will probably go back again tomorrow
author: Steve D.

description:
Another place I would have missed out on if it wasn't for Yelp.  We stopped in for lunch at around 1pm on a Thursday afternoon and the cafeteria area was only half full, so getting a seat was easy.  The ordering process at BibimBar was easy and within 3-4 minutes we had a steaming hot stone filled with awesome ingredients.

The Great:
+ I loved the fact the hot stone was hot enough to caramelize the rice.  Crunchy chewy badassery.  
+ A lot of protein for the price.  I got the pulled/shredded beef and was surpised at how much meat I got.
+ Fresh toppings.  Fresh veggies were great.

The Average:
o The spicy sauce wasn't very spicy.
o I was expecting some great kimchi, but no.

The people working the counter and line were friendly enough and I was impressed with how fast they assembled our meal.  

Overall I was very pleased with this lunch and I will absolutely be back.  Amazing value for $10.
author: Andreas H.

description:
Food is ok as far as food court expectations go.  Nothing to write home about.

Shady pricing practices, upcharged me for a side that was clearly marked for a lower price as a side on their menu (and the upcharge wasn't mentioned anywhere else).  Shady pricing practices won't bring you back customers, folks.
author: greg s.

description:
It was a good concept. It taste healthy. Nothing to write home about. I like sorobol better.
Line is long. Not sure if I would walk the 8 blocks for lunch to get this.
author: Alison W.

description: Came across this place with a friend during a weekday lunch search and while the food court decor/eating area really puts me off (it literally screams, SF Health Department, please come check me!), the food from BibimBar was pretty good!  I actually it about the same as Stone Kitchen.  My friend and I made the mistake of not ordering our food in the hot stone bowls, so by the time we got to the bottom of our bowls, not only was it cold, but I was sorely missing my "crispy" rice I usually get.  Won't happen again, that's for sure.  It's awesome that they also offer japchae noodles as an alternative, but you can also mix that with white/brown rice!  The lunch serving was definitely filling, and they don't short you on the veggies.  Would definitely come back here, but only for this place since everything else looks like it's Sketch 101.
author: Lisa I.

description: Tried this place a few weeks ago and loved it. Great Concept. Fresh food. Excellent value.
author: Joe M.

description:
This place is hard to find, but worth the hunt. Walk past the liquor store, then go down, down into a quirky Asian food court. BibimBar will have the longest line.

Everyone was ordering hot stone bowls. To the point where the staff broke into a little cheer when someone ordered a regular bowl. 

Portions are huge. You will have leftovers. But beware the spice! I ordered medium spicy and it nearly killed me! In a very delicious way.
author: Laurel K.

description:
Discovering the subterranean International Food Court (of which BibimBar is a part) was pretty awesome.

I liked the half brown rice/half japchae option and I'll probably get it again next time. A couple of things I'd do differently: I'll get a mini size (the regular is gigantic) and I'll ask for the Bibimbar spicy sauce on the side (they generously apply it and it gets a little much as you mow through the bowl).

BibimBar's a solid lunch choice, and I think I'll like it even more when I get the proportions (sauce:rice) down pat.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Pretty good place! Found it by luck when I finally decided to check out the International food court (pretty sketchy looking). 

I am glad I did because this place was very good. I got the sizzling how bowl and it customized to my liking, since they have all the ingredients there and prepare it in front of you. Highly recommended!
author: Andres M.

description:
Bibimbap for lunch - what? I thought I had to travel to the hinterlands to get dolsot bibimbap but I found it in a small food court in FiDi. You can build your own bibimbap with different "bases" (white rice, brown rice, soba noodles) and toppings (pork belly, beef, etc). I got a classic hot stone bibimbap with white rice and kimchi and pork belly which was assembled in front of me Chipotle-style. 

The food was solid and plentiful. I had hoped that the pork belly would have been more flavorful and also cut smaller, but it was still a good lunch. Next time, I'm going to ask for the sauce on the side - I ended up getting too much spicy bibimbar sauce which ended up making my bibimbap a little "one note". I got the full size but will get the mini the next time around. 

Free kimchi tofu soup on the side!
author: Wendy L.

description:
This is Korean Chipotle basically.

Spicy Pork Belly is the meat you want. Opt for the spicy 'bibim' sauce, but "not too much".
author: Ben M.

description: Don't judge a book by it's cover. Let me repeat that again - don't be afraid of this place because of its "food court" setting. BibimBar is legit the bomb dot com. This is right down the street from my office so I tend to find myself here more often than I'd like to admit but it's totally worth it!   I typically get a regular bowl with brown rice, all of the veggies, chicken, bulgogi, or spicy pork belly for a protein, kimchi, and medium spicy sauce. Every different combination I've tried has been amazing. I highly recommend this place!
author: Teresa C.

description: Not bad! Especially for Korean food in the financial district area. Decently priced too! I believe I got the beef bibimbap and my friend and I both thought that it was pretty good! I would recommend this place for those who work nearby. It's in the international food court which you have to walk downstairs to get to. The food court inside kind of looks dirty/cheap looking but there's a lot of seating area and everything in here is pretty decently priced.
author: Bailey L.

description: I love this place. Quick way to get bibimbap with lots of options. The bowls are pretty big, I'm always super stuffed after finishing a bowl. Make sure you either get there before or after the lunch rush because there will be a long line. The staff are fast so they will get to you rather quickly.
author: S. S.

description:
Quick food, under $10, and big portions? I'm game.

This place is located on Bush and it is underground. There are other restaurants around them as well, but it feels like a secret place to be. 

There is plenty of seating and the service is fast. 

I got the bulgogi bowl (never say to-go, they give you less) and it comes with a free kimchi soup. The bowl is filled with meat, rice (choice of white or brown), and veggies. Perfect for a lunch meal between work. 

You have an option of getting the small bowl or big bowl. Either way, it's both other $10. STEAL.
author: Adam J.

description:
Quick and affordable Korean food. Vegan and gluten free. Great place to get a Korean craving fix.

There are four steps: select a type of bowl, vegetables, meat and sauce. 

What you don't get are the typical complimentary side dishes but for an extra $5, i think you get some kimchi. 

It's located in a international food court where pho, Japanese, Thai and Mexican food are available.
author: Andrae V.

description:
it was ok.   Quick rice/noodle bowl.   I didn't get the heapings of meat everyone else got.  Tried it with the egg, but skip it, it is overcooked so you don't get any yolk'y goodness.

I got the marinated beef, mixed brown rice and noodle (I recommend that, it was nice to not have all rice which is too much. 

The spicy wasn't, as others mentioned.

good for a quick bowl.  wasn't a line when I got in, but when I got the food there was.   I did order to go, I am very interested in trying to stone bowl, which you can't get to go.  I just have to sucker someone into going there with me at some point.
author: Steve B.

description:
- bibimbop on an assembly line
- generous veggies
- meat was decent
- interesting that you can get brown rice and noodles as base
- nice option to have your bibimbop in a hot stone bowl (eat in only)
author: Sherry L.

description: I was really hungry and didn't know what to eat and didn't want to spent a certain amount to get the food I desired. I found Bibimbar and just ordered. It didn't take as long as I thought and even got to me before the allotted time. I didn't expect much from it since it was my first time ordering from here but it ended up being pretty good. Although, I would have wanted more spice in mine but all in all, it was a pretty darn good first experience. Oh and the delivery guy was nice too.
author: Patricia T.

description:
Oh man...I was seriously impressed to learn that a large, tasty lunch like this turned out to be only $8.63. With excellent value, this place is like the Freshroll of Korean bowl-shaped fare. You get a choice of a base (Silver noodles, brown rice, white rice), and a nice selection of veggies, meat, tofu and sauces to add on top. Other reviews suggest getting half rice and half noodles, which I think I might try next time. You can also get these ingredients in wrap-form, which might be something to try down the road.

The tofu is tasty and smothered in kimchi, and the portions are anything but skimpy. These guys go above and beyond to appreciate their customers: When you dine in, you get a complementary bowl of soup (spicy, hot, yummy), and check in to get a free drink! The service is quick and friendly. 

Located in the International Food Court, you have lots of other choices, but I think this is one I'll favor. I'll admit I'm a little giddy about discovering this place -- I'm coming back!
author: Chelsea B.

description: The International Food Court is easy to miss, but once you head downstairs from the red awning BibimBar is my favorite spot of the bunch. They serve a build-you-own Korean bowl with the option of it being served in a piping hot stone bowl (very much recommended). Great lunch spot in FiDi.
author: Matt G.

description:
It's in a food court (like in those malls)! I didn't read the reviews...I was just craving Korean food.
I usually write a thorough review but there isn't much to say. Service is fast and they assemble what you want right in front of you. I had the wrap and the tortilla stuck on to my teeth like a grill. Overall the food was good!

 It's a Korean version of Chipotle.

You can get a stamp card and they give you "bonuses" for every purchase you make.
My meal totaled $7.95 and I received a $0.15 bonus. That means I have to go there a little over 66 times to get something free (you can only redeem at $10). Which means I need to spend $530! I love Korean food but not that much...
author: Ida H.

description:
BibimBar is located within the International Food Court at Sutter and Bush. You order at the counter and find a table within the food court to enjoy your food. I typically order the Dolsot Bibimbap with pork or chicken. The whole idea is that the stone bowl is hot to cook and make the rice crispy. However, this stone bowl isn't that hot and the rice usually doesn't get too crispy. 

The food here is pretty good and a solid go-to place for lunch! The flavors are somewhat americanized but still think it's delicious. I recommend coming here especially if you are craving Korean bibimbap!
author: Lillian C.

description:
Tasty and fast! I got the spicy pork belly with the spicy sauce.. there was just enough kick for me, someone who usually likes mild-medium. I also got both brown rice and japchae which was a good mix. Total came out to be around $9 which is a little expensive for the amount but okay to me since I don't know if there are any other comparable places in the area.

I felt a little bad for the other restaurants around it in the food court since this was clearly the popular, trendy place to go. I might try the other places around it next time to try and support what I assume are the veteran restaurants.
author: Veronica C.

description: Pretty legit for a food court. I liked the pork belly rice bowl. However the price was pretty expensive and there was not enough meat for the price... Service was quick though
author: Ann L.

description: For a Quick, healthy and easy lunch go down to the International Food Court in Fidi.  The outside entrance down to food court doesn't look like much but once you get downstairs before 12 you can look at the different food station and not wait in line,  I liked the layout of Bibimbar and how you can choose to have it in 1 of 4 styles, two of 3 different bases (white, brown rice or JapChae), topping and sauce!  They are very generous and you can get a big bowl for $8.95 or so as I had the Bibimbap bowl with JapChae, Bulgogi (beef) and Sesame teriyaki, full of flavors and pickled veggies! You also get a bowl of spicy soup as well.
author: Karen W.

description: Think I ordered the wrong thing last time.  Don't get the JBap.  This is actually a good place to grab lunch assuming you order the right stuff.  The bibimbap with Spicy pork belly and fried egg is fantastic and they are usually fast and friendly too.
author: Praneeth W.

description: It has quickly become my favorite place to go for lunch when I'm at work. The bowls they make are delicious. And I'm not the only one, seeing as there is always a line when I get there after noon. I've never had a bad meal there. I would recommend that you grab it to go. Not the best seating, considering it in the international food court. But really really tasty stuff. Check it out.
author: Robert F.

description: Simply put, a healthy and fast Korean delight, especially with already super hot stone bowls which makes the rice and contents hot and crispy - so good!
author: Carlos S.

description:
Used yelp to find my way to some nearby Korean food. Wasn't wow-ed by the food or the location.

Pros: Efficient service, it's like a lunch lady style down the aisle, pick what you want; you can choose different rice or noodles and a selection of veggies and meats

Cons: The flavors aren't great and the food doesn't look that fresh

If you can find another option for Korean food, I'd recommend doing so, but if you're craving this for lunch and can't find anything else, it's an ok option.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Love that they offer japchae noodles as an option. Never had bibimbap with it, and it was yummy!

Free soup if you eat there. No ambiance, think cafeteria with no windows. Otherwise, good place to grab a quick bite with a reasonable price in the financial district.

Would have been 5 stars if the egg wasn't pre-chopped scrambled egg (vs a whole egg over easy) and there was banchan (Korean side dishes) Alas, this is more off a fast food bibimbap, so for what it is, I give it a solid 4 stars.
author: Jen Z.

description:
As sketchy as this place is...I really wanted to love it.

You'll enter through a bannered doorway that says "food court", the. You'll descend down a set of steps into a small "food court".
If you don't actively look for bibimbar, you'll probably miss it. You'll find bibimbar on the side near the steps so it's not immediately apparent.

Service was nice. No complaints. Very fast and efficient.

I ordered the bibimbap bowl with white rice. The ingredients seemed fresh enough, but it didn't stand out. It was slightly above your average bibimbap, but nothing to rave about.

I might give the pork belly a try next time and pair it up with a sodden sauce. Maybe that will change my mind.
author: Jonathan T.

description: Given what this is (a food court for lunch during the week), you'd be hard pressed to find somewhere that delivers a better Korean food experience. Service is prompt, your order is nicely customizeable and there is absolutely enough for 2 lunches if you can resist eating it all in one sitting.
author: Aaron Y.

description: The food here is okay, think Chipotle for Bibimbap. The super spicy sauce is WAY too spicy that it doesn't even make the food taste good. The medium  spicy is great but not spicy enough. You'd be better off getting medium spicy then adding sriracha. The braised tofu is very good!
author: Tanmayi S.

description: This is a great little place in a food court with a lot of variety. The food is great and their jarred kimchi is outstanding! I also drop by here at least once when I'm in SF.
author: James T.

description: Fast and delicious with that little bit of heat.  Got the pork belly yesterday and forgot to ask for the sunnyside-up egg on the top so I went back today and got the beef with that egg on top.  Had the sweet potato noodles both times.  Really tasty bowls in a convenient location.
author: Clayton L.

description:
Bi bim bap lends itself so well to a "Chipotle" style operation making BiBimBar a speedy and predictable lunch option. They were out of jap chae when I went so I stuck with brown rice but I love that they give you the option. The pork belly did have a decent amount of fat (duh, it's pork belly) but I chose it since I wanted kimchi. The sauce is standard as were the veggies. I would have liked a little bit more veggie variety but at least there was definitely some crunch in each bite. I'd return if I were back in the area.

P.S. The takeout containers are those thick plastic ones - please wash and reuse them if you can.
author: Krystle S.

description: Definitely one of my favorite lunch spot. Love how you can customize everything from rice/jap chae to protein to sauce. All for about $9-13, it's one very filling bowl! Next time I will try eating there for the hot stone bowl.
author: Lisa Z.

description: First time at this food court and I like it! It's small but offers plenty of seating and plenty of options. I went with the mini bowl with bulgogi. Perfect serving size for me. Wasn't ambitious enough to try the stone bowl but that looked great as well.
author: Linda X.

description:
For about $10 and 10 minutes, I got a sizzling bowl of delightful. Yeah, the ambiance is a little underground-Asian-stripmall-sadness, but sometimes that just makes the food seem more legit.

I got a sizzling brown rice bowl with spicy kimchi and porkbelly, and it was great! Though I wouldn't want to go for a lunch date here, if you're looking for some affordable, quick, and relatively healthy food, BibimBar is a fantastic option.

Also, I like the clever name.
author: Mari C.

description:
Solidly above average food court bibimbap.  Friendly servers.  Decent prices.  What's not to like?  Sure, the whole food court kinda feels like a dungeon, but it's like a gateway to medieval times.

"Some more of your spicy sauce on my dolsot please, fair maiden!"
author: J S.

description: An absolute gem of flavor! I work down the street and eat here so often that I've had to pull back for my wallet's sake. The ladies at the counter are sweet, and remember what I like without me having to tell them. I like to get the hot stone to crisp the noodles and keep everything warm throughout my extremely satisfying meal. Nom! I recommend this place highly.
author: Memory E.

description: Super good and filling for lunch. I got the chicken bimbimbap with all the fixings. It came with a side of soup which was not good at all; it was way too oily. Other than that I was more than satisfied with my meal. I actually like the underground cafeteria this place is in! I suggest coming early or a little later to beat the lunch crowd.
author: Samantha S.

description: Basically a Korean version of Chipotle. I like that they have stone bowls to make the rice/noodles crispy. The food was solid lunch fare, and I enjoyed the kimchi which was pleasantly surprising considering that it's just a quick lunch stop.
author: Kevin T.

description: So good I went back two days in a row. UNBELIEVABLY good! Just look for the awning that says "International" something or other, and head downstairs. I recommend half and half brown rice and noodles, spicy pork, fried egg and kimchee in the hot stone bowl, with medium sauce. Stir it around really well, and the egg cooks and the flavors are out of this world.
author: Jill C.

description:
This review is more on the service, less on the food.  Make sure you keep an eye on the flustered cashier. Not sure if she was just sidetracked or frazzled, but two things to watch out for everyone as the cashier I had is TERRIBLE! 

1) She tried to charge me for a full bowl $8.95 instead of the mini $6.95 which I had told her.

2) Then, she gave me change back for a $10 instead of a $20 that I handed her. This I know for a fact, because I had no cash on me and had to go to the ATM before lunch. She insisted it was a $10 and didn't bother looking back into the register. So basically it was my word against hers. And she was refused to believe me. 

The food is actually good.  But these last mistakes will probably have me not coming back as they actually stole money from me! 

AWFUL
author: Phillip D.

description: This is a great lunchtime option in financial district although it is on the other side of market street - I work on montgomery and mission.  but every once in awhile my coworkers and i geta group together to trek here and this is usually the most popular choice.  Five stars.
author: Daniel Y.

description: Good fast food. Tasty Bibimbap and fresh veggies!
author: Aaron G.

description: The best food in this downtown food court and the long line speaks for itself! Delicious food served by customer service driven and courteous staff. Highly recommended!
author: Philippe L.

description:
Of the few times I had gone to the International Food Court, I always chose the Vietnamese place because a) I love Vietnamese food and b) their food isn't sitting out buffet style like almost all the other places.  I also love Korean food and had been waiting for this place to open.  I finally got a chance to check it out last week and it was BOMB.

First of all, if you check in on your phone, you get a free drink.  Yay for free Fiji water (you can get a soda if that's your thing).  You just have to show your check-in to the cashier.

Second, I ordered the bulgogi in a hot stone bowl.  It was delicious!  The rice on the bottom got all crispy and crunchy and it went well with the meat, fresh veggies and spicy sauce.

Third, they give you a free bowl of tofu soup.  Yes, it was also tasty!

Fourth, the cashier also threw a side of kimchi on the side for me.  It wasn't the best I've had, but it went well with my meal.

Finally, as I was paying for my $10 meal (soup, big bowl of lunch and kimchi), the guy says - hey, we have to-go containers so bring your bowl back and we'll pack the leftovers for you.  All the other reviewers have mentioned their awesome containers.  I don't know how to describe them to you BECAUSE I ATE THE WHOLE MEAL.  

No leftovers.
SMH?  No.

WINNING!
Will def go back!
author: Lynnie P.

description: I love this place! Yes the food court itself it not great. If you are into something fancy go somewhere else or order to go! If you are looking for something tasty at a descent price, dont hesitate. Also i dont do carbs and you can easily swap the bed of rice or asian noddles (the white ones sorry cannot remember the name) by a bed of salad ir veggie. The pork belly is yummy but if you want something lighter you have salmon, chicken or just an egg. This is one of my prefered places for a quick lunch in the city.
author: Val M.

description: I had a bibimbap in hot stone bowl. It was ok, nothing spectacular. Everything was greasy, but considering the location and settings, you can't expect too much. There are better options in the food court.
author: Kinder H.

description:
If you aren't aware, this place is in the international food market on bush and kearny. It's an underground spot with about 4-5 asian restaurants. So far, I've only tried this place and pho express. I must say Bibimbar is a MUCH better choice.

I got the pork belly with brown rice and all the veggies. The pork belly was quite tasty and the veggies complimented it very well. The bowl was around $8-9 and a healthy portion. Though the line is long, it goes by pretty fast. Service was a-ok and if I'm ever craving korean food, I would definitely visit bibimbar again. 

I do wish there were more korean options in the fidi though. But this place will do for now!
author: Junel S.

description: Don't let the outside scare you away this place is a hidden gem. Food was fresh and flavorful and almost as good as when I had it in Korea
author: Ismail T.

description:
Used to be really good but has gone downhill. Got a bowl to go with chicken and the meat was under cooked to the point of almost being raw. Wound up throwing it away.

Proceed with extreme caution!
author: Rich G.

description: While not the best bibimbap I've had period, this is one of the better Korean eateries in San Fran. I got the stone bowl with bulgogi and spicy Korean sauce with an extra side of kimchi, and it did not disappoint. The kimchi was fresh and the real deal...I would pack a container and take it home if I could.The dining area is pretty small and was pretty crowded when I came (sort of like a "basement-in-the-wall"), but the food is good and the service quick.
author: Ahmed A.

description: Great option for lunch~ glad that i discovered this food court
author: Annie L.

description: Kind of a letdown. Nowhere near quality of Stone Kitchen. Much cheaper, of course.
author: Cyrus A.

description:
This is really good bibimbap with fresh vegetables. They also have brown rice. The servers are friendly.

They always have the longest line of anyone in this food court. 

4.5 stars.
author: Janet B.

description:
Don't tell me you're out of the pork belly again!?!?

Very fast, very tasty!

Very fast, still tasty (but let's be honest here), not nearly as tasty with other meats

This is close to my workplace and I come here every once in a while. Very convenient. I always get the mini because I have yet to finish a regular size. The first few times I got the typical BiBimBar sauce, but was adventurous enough to try other sauces. I came to love the spicy tomato sauce.
author: Molina T.

description: Had been a semi regular here but just went today and they discontinued their point gift card system and so my previous visits were void. Disappointing they wouldn't recognize previous visits. Given new places the same food court, don't see why their prices are worth it.
author: Yan K.

description:
First time venturing down into the International Food Court. Pretty amazing, they've got 6 restaurants down here...

The bibimbap bowl is HUGE, for $9. Your base comes with white rice, brown rice, japchae, or a combination of those three. Then veggies are piled on top, followed by your choice of meat. Add a 2nd portion of meat for $1 extra. Comes with a bowl of tofu soup. This is all nearly enough for two meals. They also had the "mini-bowl", which was $6.95. The quality was solid, not the greatest, but I've had much worse elsewhere. Lots of seating.
author: Ethan L.

description:
Not bad for a Korean lunch spot. Quick, filling, and they give you a decent amount for $9.

You pick rice or noodles, (You can do half rice and half noodles), but next time I would just do the noodles only. It was really good. Then you choose your meat, veges, and sauce. Just hits the spot.
author: Karen H.

description: Where can you get a hot stone bi bim bap in the fidi in a hot minute just blocks away from work and for a delicious price?  Down a flight of the sketchiest, slipperiest stairs ever.  If there was a cockfighting ring, it would complete the picture.  Stark fluorescent lights cast bluish shadows on all of the patrons.  Don't worry, those really are bags under my eyes.  This is not the zombie apocalypse.  Let me eat your brains.
