author: Christina C.

description: Tasty and fair price-point especially in the FiDi area! I had the dol sot (hot stone pot) rice with kimchi and spicy pork belly for under $11 after tax. Pork belly was spicy and tasty. A little fatty for me, but that's expected. Turned out more like bacon slices of goodness. Roger (owner?) is super friendly and let us sample the pork before committing. Added bonus for brown rice option no extra charge. Good amount of veggie mix. Rice doesn't get as crispy brown as usual, but that's prob due to the "bar" style of making your bowl to order. Will be coming back! Oh, free small bowl of tofu soup too! Yay!
author: dianne l.

description:
I love this place!

Line can be long during lunch hour but it moved pretty fast.  The staffs were very friendly, efficient and helpful.

I got a hot stone style .  It added $1 and only for dine in.  Be careful of the hot stone because it was still VERY HOT even after 20 minutes.  I chose brown rice with chicken and teriyaki sauce.  Standard veggies was included like lettuces, carrots, sliced egg.....with everything added up, the portion was pretty big.  I only could finish half of it.  

Regarding to the taste, not the best I have tried but it was pretty good.  The chicken was tender and tasty.  My friend got the spicy sauce and told me it was not too spicy.  Next time I will get spicy sauce because teriyaki sauce was kinda tasteless.  

I don't know they can mix the base like half rice and half noodle after I ordered.  I will do that next time.
author: Liza T.

description:
Holler, I just found my lunch-hood bibimbop location!!!

Bibimbar is da bomb - they're friendly, they give HUGE portions, they have STONE CLAY bowls - which in my option is the only way to dine with bibimbop AND they give you globs and globs of spicy sauce and extra if you want it.

Free tofu soup too that was mighty tasty.

Generous amount of veggies and meat.

CHEAP.  Kinda in a dungeon and underground - so if you're not into these type of places, beware!
author: Jana S.

description: Great value. Really quite happy with my mini pork belly bowl. Free tofu soup hit the spot. So did the jap chae noodles instead of rice. SCORE!
author: Andrew K.

description: Simple stall in this asian food court. The bibimbap is actually quite solid if you feel like Korean food - it definitely hits the spot sometimes during lunch.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Absolutely love this place, it's not the best bibimbap I've had however it is still very good, especially in the Stone bowl!

One thing I do wish they would give is an option of Kimchi on the side, besides this it is basically a "build your own bibimbap," and the sauce is excellent! I haven't tried any other restaurants in this food court since this place just calls to me before I get a chance to look at others :)

It's the only korean place I like near my work that is walkable!
author: Matt T.

description:
Noodle on it.

Korean food as a burrito.
Noodles replacing rice.
Sesame teriyaki marinade replacing sour cream and/or guacamole.

It's happening. Right here.

You can choose other styles like a salad or bowl. All you need is a meat base (like the delicious marinated chicken), toppings and sauce.

How it comes together is up to you.

Strongly recommend the wrap. Just so you can say you had noodles inside a flour tortilla. It's different. It's awesome.

Not everything was perfect. Gentleman started making my food after using his phone but before washing his hands. Accidently charged extra for beef instead of chicken.

In both instances there were apologies and corrections. Place was busy. Mistakes happen. All is good.

Just like the food.
author: Jason B.

description: Great lunchtime option in the area when you don't feel like waiting in line for Sushirrito or Curry Up. Korean bibimbap goodness which will make you feel good inside! If you decide to go for a sit-down lunch they also do hot stone (dolsot) bibimbap.
author: Joffrey F.

description: everything I wanted. vegan. perfect. great pricing. highly recommend.
author: C Z.

description:
I did not have a pleasant experience here.

The people making my bowl were nice and direct. Very efficient for the lunch crowd looking to get in/out easily. However, the Korean lady behind was quite rude to the staff and myself.

The situation:

I was standing in line and there was a Korean guy 2 people behind me. I know this because the lady behind the counter asked him and he politely nodded in agreement. 

I get to the front of the line and it's my turn to pay. I hand the cashier my credit card, she swipes it, and is about to hand me my food. However, the Korean lady jumps in and attempts to push everything out of the way so the Korean guy can pay for his stuff first. He didn't have it pre-made or anything, I saw his bowl being prepared the same as us all. I tell her that I just paid and my bowl is sitting 2 feet from me, just hand it over and we're done with the transaction.

Nope, she insists that the cashier made a mistake and set my stuff to the side. I tell her I just paid and I see the guy attempt to usher me out of the way, but I hold my ground and tell her that my bowl is right in front of her. She eventually hands it to me and then let's the Korean guy pay right away...

Is this even worth complaining about? Seems ridiculous, right? Of all the crap we have to put up with on this planet... this... this is what I choose to complain about, "oh some lady wanted to let some other guy cut in front of mes" Doesn't really matter in the large scope of things, but maybe there's something deeper going on here. I don't know, but  what I do know is that it bothered me enough to write a negative Yelp review...

Ok, so maybe next time I'll just tell the dickhead behind me to wait his damn turn.

Actual useful information:
- The food is decent. House of Lumpia next to it is a lot better.
- They need to reverse the layout of the food so the rice/vegetables is at the start and the meat/toppings are at the end. This would prevent the staff from going back/forth a bunch.
- Let the staff do their job and stop micromanaging.
author: Nick E.

description: It's healthy, fast and delicious Korean BBQ with tons of veggies over rice or noodle.  It is located in the heart of Financial district and close to my work.  I will definately come back:)
author: A I.

description:
I love this place so much that I've been known to eat here 3 days in a row. The bibimbap bowls are flavorful, healthy, quick, and cheap, and the mini bowl is perfect for those days when you don't have as big of an appetite. 

For the bowl, you get to choose whether you want brown rice or clear noodles (or both), your choice of meat (or tofu/kimchee for the vegetarians), and an assortment of toppings. I've had the shrimp and tofu and both are superb. Add all the toppings. 

The international food court is a little odd from the outside as it's in the basement wit no grand entrance, but the area is actually really large and can host large groups for lunch. 

The only reason I'm subtracting one star is because they're often out of the clear noodles. Those noodles are what really make the dish for me, so when they're out I just get sad. I've replaced them with soba (which is more expensive) but it's really not the same type of noodle at all and doesn't work as well with the dish.
author: Anya P.

description:
I got the regular bowl with bulgogi and all veggies, extra spicy sauce. veggies were awesome, rice was warm and sticky, bulgogi was meh. The line was fast, and the service was awesome. Can't hate too much on the bulgogi since it's a quick-service format, and in general I've just been spoiled by LA and DC korean food. For under $10, I got massively full, and also got a bowl of spicy soup.

Do it.
author: Alex L.

description: My gf was craving bibimbap, so we decided to try this place out.  The bowl is $7.50 which comes with your choice of sauce and starch (rice, brown rice, or noodles).  An assortment of vegetables comes with it too.  Meat, eggs, kimchi, etc.. are considered add-ons and range from maybe $1-$3 EACH.  So I would considered this place $$ not $ - it can get pricey, but does not have to be.  The lady was very nice and super friendly.  She gave us some pork belly to try, which was really good - better than the bulgogi.  The portion is actually really good for the price.  You will be stuffed!  Since this place is in the international food court, everything is prepared already.  They just grab everything and throw in a bowl.  I really enjoyed the food and found it to be delicious and would definitely come back.  I recommend you guys to go check it out!  The service is 5/5 - the lady is very sweet!  This place was kind of hard to find, since the sign is small.  You will see a bibimbar sign on the outside or international food court with a door that makes you walk down to the food court.
author: Kevin N.

description: I found out about this place yesterday through my friend. I recommend to get stone pot. I had mild spicy but I'll get spicier option when I go the next time. It's really goo lunch option for people who work in the Financial District and Union Square.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: Expensive! Small ball with little things don't get you feel anything. Over $11. They taste ok, the beef is a bit too sweet.
author: Shin T.

description: The pork belly with kimchee bibimbap is a nice touch in a section of SF where Korean food is scarce. The meal was satisfying if you are in the mood for K-food and are lingering in FiDi. International Food Court? I kept thinking of a shopping mall, like Stonestown or Westfields. But this place is down a flight of some strange stairs near the corner of Bush and Kearny. 3.5 rounding up to 4.0
author: Derek N.

description: The veggies are so disappointing!! No effort in them at all! It's lettuce/cabbage with your choice of a meat (overly sweet)...and the rice isn't even cooked in the stone bowls like it should be.For $11? Methinks not.
author: Baviera K.

description: This place sells some legit Dol-Sot Bibimbap.  Best to get it with bulgogi + noodles + ggo-choo-jang (original spicy sauce).  They give you kimchi soup for free if you eat it there.  I have a pretty big appetite and I was barely able to finish it.  Portions are freakin HUGE.
author: JD K.

description: The BibimBar is an affordable option in the financial district when compared to the other Korean Bibimbap. This place serves brown rice and if its cold (which is more often then not) I would advise going with the stone bowel as it magically makes the food taste better. The portion size is the perfect amount and if anything this is one of the top three choices at the international food court.
author: Ryan C.

description: Enjoyed the fresh ingredients and friendly costumer service. The nice stylish gentleman with the awesome trucker hat and semi longish hair resembled a young jim morrison... He was also very helpful. They sure know how to cook bulgogi!
author: Ronnie P.

description:
I went here twice in a week shortly after I discovered it, so I guess I must have liked it.  Honestly the staff are nice, it's fast, and they are sensitive to food needs (i.e., vegetarian or vegan), so that's great. The food is good and spicy, if you want it that way, and the prices seem reasonable.

I guess the only reason I'm not giving it 4+ stars is because, like other meals in the FiDi that someone composes with tongs from a steam tray for me in record speed, it's not as good as it could be--like a fast food version of real bibimbap. Maybe that's just because I know how good bibimbap can be. But real Korean food is not really ever vegetarian, so in the meantime I'll probably come back here every once in awhile to satisfy my kimchi craving.
author: Tamara F.

description: My coworkers ordered from here on my first day at work for a team lunch. It was delicious, yes, but not as "authentic" as I would have liked. I got the kimchi and pork belly with spicy sauce. It was moderately spicy and WHERE WAS THE KIMCHI?! At most Korean places, they are very generous with kimchi. I guess because it's dumped in all together instead of a separate container for delivery, they mute it down for those that don't like kimchi? I have no idea. I'll definitely order again but that was very disappointing.
author: Diana Z.

description: Found this place in the food court.  Decent prices.  Food was better than more expensive Korean Bar B Que places I've tried.  Will definitely add it to my lunch rotation.
author: Keith S.

description: Outstanding service, great value and ultimately a delicious way to slip into a gut-bomb induced 2:30pm nap.  Be sure to check the countertops for check-in specials (Yelp, Foursquare, Facebook etc).
author: Dean F.

description: Unspectacular bibimbap (brown rice, half tofu, half bulgogi, spicy sauce). Quick, friendly service.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Hmm...it's veggies and rice in a bowl for 8 bucks. Real bibimbap has a lovely, aromatic sesame oil fragrance/flavor. This does not. Still on the hunt for good bibim!
author: Tara S.

description: the bibim bap here, despite it being avg $10 a bowl, is delicious. you can get both rice and jap chae. as a recent korean transplant in the city, i was dying to get some decent korean food around work. if you work near here, it's definitely worth walking over to for lunch. i would not drive here though, there should be better korean food places you can go to if you have a car (god i hope) -_-.
author: C. L.

description: I'd been looking for a decent Korean place in the financial district for months when I accidentally stumbled onto this place in the International Food Court.  I got the Hot Stone BulGoGi (marinated beef) with free soup.  Not the best but was good.  The service was great.  I gave 4 stars for the quantity and price.  Can't beat that in FiDi.
author: Clear P.

description: I got the half noodles, half brown rice bowl with spicy pork and bibimbar sauce on the side. This is my new go-to lunch joint in Fidi. I couldn't finish the whole bowl, but kept eating because it was so good. The spicyness was just right for me. I wasn't reaching out for milk or jugs of water with each bite. I was actually enjoying the flavor.
author: Famela O.

description:
Had the hot stone with bulgogi and bibimbar spicy sauce. It had lots of veggies and plenty of meat. It also came with a small bowl of tofu soup. All this for $10. Only thing is the rice isn't cooked in the stone pot. If it was, the rice would be slightly crispy at the bottom. I understand. This place is fast food. If they really cooked the rice in the stone pot, it would take too long. 

I'll definitely come back. It's a deal for all the food you get!
author: Linda Y.

description: Great bibimbap, friendly service. The marinated tofu is great. Definitely get the spicy sauce.
author: Gene G.

description: Good food, filling and great service. Good unique alternative to the otherwise stale options in the area. Try the kimchee pork belly!
author: Tony B.

description:
I had the bibimbap at Have a Rice Day which is a block away and wanted to try this place for comparison. I'm surprised that people are giving this place such high ratings. I ordered the bulgogi bibimbap with all vegetables.

The bulgogi was marinated and had more flavor than the beef at Have a Rice Day.
The items may have been a little more sweet/tart.

There's less variety with the vegetables, the serving seems smaller, but it ended up being more expensive than the bibimbap at Have a Rice Day which doesn't make sense. The egg is sliced instead of being whole and I think they used arugula which I didn't enjoy.

I'd love to have the other reviewers here try Have a Rice Day and hear their thoughts/comparisons.
author: John N.

description:
They're to-go containers are solid, and microwave safe.  I take these things home and keep them as cheap Tupperware (or Glad, if you prefer not to get mad).  

I like to go there at 2 p.m. so that I can watch Who Wants to Be a Millionaire and so the food court is as crazily crowded and messy as tends to be.  Also, smaller lines! 

And speaking of the awesome to-go containers, I can never finish the hot stone, so I always have left overs, and I like to think I got TWO meals for $10 instead of just one meal.  So, if you're like me and can't finish a regular/medium bowl of pho, you'll probably end up with leftovers as well.

One time I got the wrap, though, which was pretty good, but I'd probably rather have the rice bowl or a regular burrito. Try it, though, if you really like Asian burritos.  That's not a euphemism, by the way.  

Oh, and in reply to the other user who said that they don't cook the rice in the hot stone--the rice does, indeed, cook in the hot stone, but you have to wait a bit for the rice on the bottom to get nice and crispy.  Speaking of the hot stone, that's my usual order.  The pork belly is prettyyyy nice.  And just a tip: if you're afraid of the Bibimbar spicy sauce being too spicy for you, well...it's not.  It's less spicy that hot cheetos.  And pretty good, so you might want to try it (unless hot cheetos are too much for you).

Oh, and they give kimchi on the side now.  Mmm.  

And I know most people don't really care about this, given that it's a food court, but the servers are pretty friendly.  Once, they ran out of something (I forgot what, though...) and someone (the...owner?) offered to make some more for me, if I didn't mind waiting.  Unfortunately, I have a very short lunch break for work, so no *insert whatever it was* for me that day.

OH AND FOR A LIMITED TIME OFFER, EVERY TIME YOU CHECK IN ON FACEBOOK/YELP/WHATHAVEYOU, YOU GET A FREE DRINK.  SO GET ON THAT.
author: Jannelle Z.

description: This place is pretty good even though it's relatively underground. No, literally, It's underground. I recommend mixing the noodles with brown rice.
author: Tyler P.

description: The bibimbap was way too sweet.  They put way too much sugar in their food.  If you want to guzzle water for a long time or you just love sweet Korean food, then this is the place for you.  I think I'm going to go back to my usual Have a Rice Day for their bibimbap.
author: I L.

description: Tasty rice bowl!  Dependably good, inexpensive vegetarian rice bowl- I go for brown rice (choice of white/brown rice or glass noodles), all the vegies (no tofu or meat), and spicy sauce.   Hearty helping.  Comes with a warm bowl of spicy soup.  Beef bulgogi was also very tasty.
author: Clark C.

description: The bowl was just OK.  I was kind of disappointed with the raw cabbage and shredded iceberg lettuce in my bowl.  I felt like those were fillers and that the iceberg lettuce was a sad disappointment for what i wished was kimchee.   Needless to say the iceberg lettuce and shredded cabbage were really bland. The beef was OK.  The spicy sauce seemed really mild.  Alas, the kimchee costs extra.  As does the fried egg. I would have enjoyed it more if i didn't feel like i was being nickel and dimed.
author: Freedy H.

description: I had a really great experience here. Great food, authentic and yummy. Customer service was good too. Definitely will be going back.
author: Liz P.

description: i love this place!  I think it is the best hot stone place in SF!  Super flavorful.  The spicy bibimbar sauce isn't spicy though, just a heads up.

description: The bim bim bap was not bad. But the complimentary micro-wave friendly box is fabulous!
author: Shirley W.

description:
I'd been looking for a decent Korean place in the financial district for months when I accidentally stumbled onto this place in the International Food Court. For those of you who have never been to the International Food Court, it's a dodgy, dirty little underground food court that sold cheap not-tasty asian food. That was until Bibimbar opened. I had very low expectations since I've tried the other food here and was unimpressed but I figured I'd give it a shot. I really, really love bibimbop and being half Korean, I am pretty picky about my Korean food. (Nothing can compare to mama's homemade bbq and kimchi.) 
I order the bibimbop with half rice and half noodles, all the veggies, bulgogi and their spicy bibimbar sauce. The veggies are all fresh and delicious. The bulgogi is awesome and for under $10 I always have enough for 2 meals. Of course, I am a total glutton and ended up stuffing myself with the entire bowl today. I'm ready to slip into my food coma now...
I literally eat here at least 3 times a week. The service is great and the food is delicious. You really can't beat it. 
Nothing will ever be as good as mom's but this place will definitely keep me coming back for more.
author: Tish B.
